text: Is there a existing function that does this `f(::Val{T}) where T = T` ?

elements.text: Is there a existing function that does this

text: `f(::Val{T}) where T = T`  <-- there it is  [so, no there is no preexisting version of that]

elements.text: <-- there it is  [so, no there is no preexisting version of that]

text: What does this do? What is the `where T = T` doing?

elements.text: What does this do? What is the

text:
Read it likes this, I guess
```julia> function f(::Val{T}) where T 
           return T 
       end```

elements.text: Read it likes this, I guess

julia> function f(::Val{T}) where T 
           return T 
       end

text: Yep, it just extracts the parameter from a Val. The idea of Val is to move a value from runtime to compile time, and this function moves it back to runtime

elements.text: Yep, it just extracts the parameter from a Val. The idea of Val is to move a value from runtime to compile time, and this function moves it back to runtime

text: `where T`  is important so that it allows you to use T in the actual function definition/code block. Otherwise it thinks that T inside the code block is just an undefined variable (anthromorphizing but yeah)

elements.text: is important so that it allows you to use T in the actual function definition/code block. Otherwise it thinks that T inside the code block is just an undefined variable (anthromorphizing but yeah)

text:
Example:
```julia> function f(::Val{T})
           return T
       end
ERROR: UndefVarError: T not defined
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[1]:1

julia> function f(::Val{T}) where T
           return T
       end
f (generic function with 1 method)```

           return T
       end
